title: Literally Guilty Until Proven Innocent
content: John Grisham's latest legal thriller, "The Guardians," traces the steps of Cullen Post and the other lawyers and investigators of a nonprofit organization dedicated to proving the innocence of incarcerated persons who were wrongfully convicted.  The Guardian Ministry has a track record of having secured the release of 8 persons. This case concerns Quincy Miller, who has been on death row for 22 years.  The evidence against Miller, accused of murdering his divorce lawyer,  seems so sketchy, but once a jury found him guilty, it is exceedingly difficult to undo the damage.  As Post investigates, he realizes he is up against an elaborate conspiracy featuring well-connected players with deep pockets who will go to any lengths not to have Miller exonerated.  Post's efforts are complicated by shortcomings of the  initial investigation, planted and missing evidence, the perjury of witnesses, crooked local officials,  prison gangs, and drug cartels.  True to his typical writing style, Grisham provides a  straightforward, fast-moving pace, with intricate details and subplots that will make a reader wonder if it is too late (or too dangerous) for the Guardians to  uncover the real culprits so that Quincy Miller can be set free. According to the author's note, this book was inspired by separate true events.

title: Not the typical Grisham legal thriller
content: John Grisham is one of my favorite authors and I have read all of his legal thrillers, excluding the Theodore Boone series.  The Guardians distinguishes itself from his former legal thrillers in that it focuses on legal exoneration--getting convicted murderers exonerated after years and decades of serving time for a crime not committed.  This book is about social injustice, why it occurs, and how devastating it can be on a human being's life.  It is also about lawyers who work for years without the high compensation of most lawyers to see that people wrongly convicted have a shot at freedom.  Cullen Post is one such lawyer--a good man using his talents and limited resources to right serious wrongs.  Because of the nature of the two main cases in The Guardians, the typical legal intrigue in a Grisham legal thriller is missing.  That said, the book is very interesting and informative about a serious issue in America--legal injustice, especially for black males.  The last 30 pages of the book are worth the price of the book.  I highly recommend The Guardians.

title: Verified Purchase
content: After the unimaginative fluff of Camino Winds, John Grisham returns to what he does best:  Writing a legal thriller which, though fiction, is thoroughly grounded in reality.  In an afterword, he identifies a couple of real-life cases in which innocent people have been incarcerated and dedicated lawyers have fought to exonerate them.  Cullen Post, the protagonist, is a lawyer turned priest turned lawyer again.  Because of this, he has a depth of commitment not often seen in attorneys.  His work with Guardian Ministries (read The Innocence Project) is indeed holy work, and it takes him on long road trips across the modern South.  Post, as he prefers to be called, runs down witnesses who lied in the trial which put his client in prison for life twenty-three years ago.  There are some surprising twists, some colorful characters on both sides of the law, and an immensely satisfying ending.  Highly recommended.

title: This Book Inspired Me!
content: As a lawyer I'm always dismayed by how little the general public understands  about the legal system which has been forged in this country to protect their rights. It's often not until average folks come face to face with justice, whether as a party to a claim, a victim of injustice, or juror, do they really begin to understand what's at stake and how easily the law can be misused and justice denied! John Grisham's  latest novel provides an opportunity for all of us to consider how important affording equal protection and treatment to all is in this system as well as how important checks and balances are both before and after a conviction.  This book is a sobering reminder that there are dedicated lawyers who face extraordinary hurdles every day to protect and defend us yet receive little in return for their dedication. Hopefully this will change, but for now supporting their efforts is up to the rest of us.

content: I am not one to want to read books with a partisan view of what is going on today. We get enough of that every day, 24/7 in the news. Justice reform is very much in the news and justifiable so, and i was wondering if this would be another partisan book. It was not. It was great. It brought attention to this cause with a very interesting layout of how a very innocent person could be framed up and by the people who are supposed to be fair. I love that it brought much needed attention to the innocent project. This story was based on a true story. Thank goodness for lawyers who will try and do the right thing vs. being only about the money. It was a fast read and i never wanted to put it down. Loved it

title: Not Your Typical Grisham
content: Cullen Post a Lawyer and Episcopal Priest works for Guardian Ministries  a Pro Bono non profit that specializes in attempting to overturn the convictions of men that have been imprisoned for 15-20 years that in fact were innocent. In most cases the men that were convicted are black and were convicted by white police, white judges and all white juries. The book deals with such a person Quincy Miller who is serving a 23 year sentence . There are a lot of moving parts in this book lots of names and lots of locations you have to pay attention.  Overall itâ€™s a good read so you should read it

title: Good Read
content: I've enjoyed John Grisham's fictional legal novels over the decades - this book was no exception.  The storyline has a bit more of a window into the background logistical detail of the Innocence Projects than I might have preferred, but it never completely got in the way of the fictional plot line.  The final chapters of the book are "classic" Grisham...building suspense and a sense of urgency to "beat the clock" and deliver - what the reader hopes will be - a fair and just conclusion.

title: Verified Purchase
content: So, a fun ride in the quest for justice for an innocent man. (That awful scene of torture with the bag of bloody chickens and two naked boys (why two?) being tossed into a river of crocodiles was over the top!). But the deliberate unfolding and discovery of events that led to the wrongful conviction is well-paced. There is the final courtroom retrial which is satisfying, too. But we've seen this from Grisham before... I had fun reading this as the pace doesn't lag. Interesting characters, but so many colorful Southern lawyers and lawmen. Hard to keep track of who is who... There will be a movie soon, no doubt...

title: A new but old Grisham thriller
content: There is a lot to learn before feeling like it is easy to read.  When all the players are in place, the book really takes off.  It is a beautiful idea to help those innocent people who have been judged guilty and incarcerated.  It is an amazing story that Grisham wrote about all the possible things someone goes through to prove the incarcerated person is innocent.  More power to them.  A great book.  It just took me a while for the book to get a hold of me!

title: Verified Purchase
content: As always, Grisham delivers a first class novel. The Guardians is a crisp easy read that keeps the reader turning the pages. There is one flaw. While describing one of the characters, Mazy Ruffin, Grisham refers to her educational background noting that she attending Morehouse College. Morehouse, a HBBU, is a traditional male private university. Mazy would have been allowed to take classes as part of the consortium of schools in that area but she would not have been a graduate. It's a small oversight but it caught my attention. Otherwise, this is a great book.
